Article.Abstract: The cytotoxic T cell response against lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) in BALB/c (H-2d) mice is predominantly directed against a single immunodominant Ld-restricted epitope in the viral nucleoprotein (NP118-126). Here we report that the immunodominance of this peptide can be in part attributed to its very high affinity for Ld class I molecules. By employing motif searches and sensitive MHC class I binding assays, we also identified 5 Kd-binding peptides in the viral nucleoprotein and glycoprotein among 16 Kd motif-fitting peptides. The nucleoprotein and glycoprotein sequences also contained 18 Dd motif-fitting peptides, three of which bound Dd with weak affinity. Two of the Kd-binding peptides, residues 99-108 and residues 283-291 from the viral glycoprotein, are subdominant epitopes. Although these peptides did not sensitize target cells for direct ex vivo killing by primary antiviral CTL, secondary responses against these peptides were readily detected in BALB/c mice after acute LCMV infection. BALB/c mice that had cleared a long-term LCMV infection showed more sustained CTL responses against these subdominant epitopes, suggesting that subdominant responses might play a role in clearance of chronic infections. One of the subdominant epitopes, GP283-291, conferred partial protection against persistent viral infection after peptide vaccination.
Article.ArticleTitle: Analysis of cytotoxic T cell responses to dominant and subdominant epitopes during acute and chronic lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus infection.
Article.Affiliations: Emory Vaccine Center and Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA 30322, USA.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Viral;H-2 Antigens;Immunodominant Epitopes;Peptides;Vaccines, Synthetic;Viral Proteins;Viral Vaccines
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Acute Disease; Animals; Antigens, Viral(immunology); Chronic Disease; Cytotoxicity, Immunologic; H-2 Antigens(immunology); Immunity, Cellular; Immunodominant Epitopes; Lymphocytic Choriomeningitis(immunology); Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus(immunology); Mice; Mice, Inbred BALB C; Peptides(chemistry; immunology); T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology); Vaccines, Synthetic(immunology); Viral Proteins(chemistry; immunology); Viral Vaccines(immunology)

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide immunized mice were challenged with LCMV clone 28b. Mice were challenged 14 days after vaccination and virus titers in serum were determined. GP314-322 did not confer any protection.

Spleen cells were prepared 8 days after the immunization.This peptide was not recognized during primary antiviral response. In another experiment, no specific lysis was observed when a secondary in vitro stimulation with the peptide was performed.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide immunized mice were challenged with LCMV clone 28b. Mice were challenged 14 days after vaccination and virus titers in serum were determined. GP44-51 did not confer any protection.

Spleen cells were prepared 8 days after the immunization.This peptide was recognized during primary antiviral response. In another experiment, specific lysis was observed when a secondary in vitro stimulation with the peptide was performed.

Spleen cells were prepared from mice that had undergone a chronic infection with LCMV variant A22-2b. More than one year after infection, spleen cells were stimulated with the peptide and the peptide-specific CTL activity was tested. Stimulation with this subdominant peptide yielded a significant peptide-specific CTL response. This response is sustained more efficiently under conditions of prolonged antigenic stimulation.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Peptide was dissolved in PBS and injected s.c. at the base of the tail.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Secondary responses were determined 12 days after vaccination. The number of effector cells giving 30% specific lysis in a standard chromium release was evaluated. GP283-291, a subdominant epitope is immunogenic. Lysis of LCMV-infected targets was far lower than killing of peptide-coated targets, indicating that GP283-291 is poorly processed.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide immunized mice were challenged with LCMV clone 28b. Mice were challenged 14 days after vaccination and virus titers in serum were determined. GP99-108 is not protective even though it was found to be immunogenic.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Secondary responses were determined 12 days after vaccination. The number of effector cells giving 30% specific lysis in a standard chromium release was evaluated. GP99-108, a subdominant epitope is immunogenic. Lysis of LCMV-infected targets was slightly better than killing of peptide-coated targets, indicating that GP99-108 is processed efficiently.

Spleen cells were prepared from mice that had undergone a chronic infection with LCMV variant A22-2b. More than one year after infection, spleen cells were stimulated with the peptide and the peptide-specific CTL activity was tested. Stimulation with this subdominant peptide yielded a significant peptide-specific CTL response. This response is sustained more efficiently under conditions of prolonged antigenic stimulation.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Secondary responses were determined 12 days after vaccination. The number of effector cells giving 30% specific lysis in a standard chromium release was evaluated. GP99-108, a subdominant epitope is immunogenic. Lysis of LCMV-infected targets was slightly better than killing of peptide-coated targets, indicating that GP99-108 is processed efficiently.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide immunized mice were challenged with LCMV clone 28b. Mice were challenged 14 days after vaccination and virus titers in serum were determined. NP118-126 confers excellent protection.

Spleen cells were prepared 8 days after the immunization.This peptide was not recognized during primary antiviral response. In another experiment, no specific lysis was observed when a secondary in vitro stimulation with the peptide was performed.

Spleen cells were prepared from mice that had undergone a chronic infection with LCMV variant A22-2b. More than one year after infection, spleen cells were stimulated with the peptide and the peptide-specific CTL activity was tested. As in the acute infection, this peptide was still immunodominant after clearance of the chronic infection.

Spleen cells were prepared 8 days after the immunization.This peptide was recognized during primary antiviral response. In another experiment, specific lysis was observed when a secondary in vitro stimulation with the peptide was performed.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Peptide was dissolved in PBS and injected s.c. at the base of the tail.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Secondary responses were determined 12 days after vaccination. The number of effector cells giving 30% specific lysis in a standard chromium release was evaluated. NP118-126, an immunodominant epitope is immunogenic. Lysis of LCMV-infected targets was higher than killing of peptide-coated targets, indicating that NP118-126 is processed efficiently.
